chapter: Acid-Base Balance  Renal Hormones and Micturiti

questions.question: Question 1: Principal site of acidification of urine
questions.explanation:
Principal site of acidification of urine is collecting duct. Acidification occurs in both distal tubule 
and collecting duct, but collecting duct is more important. The urinary pH of 4.5 (limiting pH) is normally reached in the collecting ducts. In the late distal tubules and collecting ducts, the tubular epithelium secretes H+ by primary 
active transport. Primary active secretion of H+ occurs in type A intercalated cells of the late distal 
tubule and in the collecting tubules. H+ concentration can be increased as much as 900-fold in 
the collecting tubules.
questions.chapter_heading: Acid-Base Balance  Renal Hormones and Micturiti

questions.question: Question 2: Most important extracellular buffer
questions.explanation:
The most important extracellular buffer is bicarbonate. The source of bicarbonate is plasma by 
filteration. It is a non inducible buffer. Proteins: Are the most abundant intracellular buffer. Phosphate: minor buffer in kidney. The source is plasma by filteration. It is a noninducible 
buffer. Ammonia is a minor buffer, locally produced by tubular cells. Its production increases in 
metabolic acidosis. It is the only inducible buffer.
questions.chapter_heading: Acid-Base Balance  Renal Hormones and Micturiti

questions.question: Question 3: Normal anion gap is mostly due to
questions.explanation:
Normal anion gap is mostly due to unmeasured proteins. Normally in the plasma, the concentrations of anions and cations are equal to maintain electrical 
neutrality. Thus no real "anion gap" exists in the plasma and this is purely a diagnostic concept. Diagnostically, when the electrolytes are measured in the blood, routinely only certain cations and 
anions are measured. These are Na+, Cl- and HCO3-. The anion gap is the difference between the 
unmeasured anions and unmeasured cations. This is estimated as : Plasma anion gap= [Na+] - [Cl-] - [HCO3-] 685 
Sold by @itachibot The unmeasured cations include calcium, magnesium and potassium. The unmeasured anions include albumin, phosphate, sulphate and organic anions. This is primarily used in measurement of different causes of metabolic acidosis.
questions.chapter_heading: Acid-Base Balance  Renal Hormones and Micturiti

questions.question:
Question 4: Normal anion gap is  
mEq / L.
questions.explanation:
The normal anion gap ranges between 8 and 16 mEq/L. The concentrations of anions and cations in plasma must be equal to maintain electrical 
neutrality. Therefore, there is no real “anion gap” in the plasma. However, only certain cations and anions are routinely measured in the clinical laboratory. The 
cation normally measured is Na+, and the anions are usually Cl and HCO3. The “anion gap” (which is only a diagnostic concept) is the difference between unmeasured anions 
and unmeasured cations and is estimated as Plasma anion gap = [Na+ ]  [HCO3 ]  [Cl ]=14424108 =12 mEq/L The anion gap will increase if unmeasured anions rise or if unmeasured cations fall. The most important unmeasured cations include calcium, magnesium and potassium and the 
major unmeasured anions are albumin, phosphate, sulfate and other organic anions. Usually the unmeasured anions exceed the unmeasured cations and the anion gap ranges between 
8 and 16 mEq/L.
questions.chapter_heading: Acid-Base Balance  Renal Hormones and Micturiti

questions.question: Question 5: Endocrine functions associated with kidney include all of the following except
questions.explanation:
ANP is secreted by the heart. Endocrine/Paracrine Functions of the Kidney: Substance 
Site of secretion Renin 
Granular cells or juxtaglomer 
ular cells (JG cells) of the jux 
taglomerular apparatus (JGA) Erythropoietin 
Interstitial cells in the peritu 
bular capillary bed Prostaglandin E2 (PGE2) 
Renal medullary interstitial c 
ells (RMICs), macula densa, 
and by cells of collecting duct Arterioles and glomeruli PGI2and other prostaglandin 
s 1,25-Dihydroxycholecalciferol Cells of proximal tubules of t 
he kidneys. (calcitriol or vitamin D3) 686 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.chapter_heading: Acid-Base Balance  Renal Hormones and Micturiti

questions.question: Question 6: The major prostanoid synthesized in kidney is
questions.explanation:
PGE2 is the major prostanoid synthesized in the kidney. It is secreted by: • RMICs (Renal Medullary Interstitial Cells) • Macula densa • Cells in the collecting ducts. Prostacyclin (PGI2) and other prostaglandins are secreted by the arterioles and glomeruli. Renal medullary interstitial cells (RMICs) are specialized fibroblast-like cells which are major site 
of cyclooxygenase 2 (COX-2) and prostaglandin synthase (PGES) expression.
questions.chapter_heading: Acid-Base Balance  Renal Hormones and Micturiti

questions.question:
Question 7: All of the following results in increased renin secretion except  
.

options.b: Increased amount of Na+ in DCT
options.c: Decreased amount of Na+ in PCT

questions.explanation:
The increased amount of Na+ and Cl- reabsorption across macula densa (DCT) is inhibitory to 
renin secretion. All other factors increase renin secretion. Renin leads to a series of events through the Renin-Angiotensin-Aldosterone pathway that finally, 
in simple terms, leads to salt and water retention and increases blood pressure. Therefore, it is 
easy to remember that all factors that cause decreased effective volume, pressure, or sodium 
delivery will increase the renin levels and vice versa. Note: Renin is secreted by the juxtaglomerular cells (granular cells) which are epitheloid cells 
located in the media of afferent arterioles of the glomerulus.
questions.chapter_heading: Acid-Base Balance  Renal Hormones and Micturiti

questions.question: Question 8: Angiotensin II causes all of the following except
questions.explanation:
Angiotensin II is one of the most potent vasoconstrictors in the body. It constricts efferent arteriole, thereby increasing filteration fraction and glomerular filteration 
rate, when there is decreased renal bloodflow
questions.chapter_heading: Acid-Base Balance  Renal Hormones and Micturiti

questions.question: Question 9: Vasopressin secretion is increased by
questions.explanation:
Vasopressin (ADH) secretion increases in response to decreased ECF volume to bring about water 
retention to restore the ECF volume. ADH exerts its antidiuretic effect by acting on the V2 receptors and involves the insertion of 
aquaporin 2 (AQP2) into the apical (luminal) membranes of the principal cells of the collecting 
ducts. 687 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.chapter_heading: Acid-Base Balance  Renal Hormones and Micturiti

questions.question:
Question 10: A patient who got into an accident is brought to the casualty and is bleeding from his right 
leg. His blood pressure is 90/60 mm Hg. Which of the following plays the most important 
role for sodium and water retention in this patient?
questions.explanation:
The renin-angiotensin system plays the most important role for sodium and water retention in 
this patient as the patient has hypovolemia due to blood loss. (refer to figure) The plasma concentration of renin is the rate-limiting step in the renin-angiotensin system; it is 
the major determinant of plasma angiotensin II concentration. Angiotensin II stimulates the aldosterone and ADH secretion; it also constricts the blood vessels 
and causes thirst, which helps in maintaining blood pressure.
questions.chapter_heading: Acid-Base Balance  Renal Hormones and Micturiti

questions.question: Question 11: Atriopeptin (ANP) acts at
questions.explanation:
ANP acts on the collecting duct. ANP is secreted by the atria in response to an increase in ECF volume. It decreases Na+ 
reabsorption in the late distal tubule and collecting ducts. It causes natriuresis. ANP causes dilation of afferent arterioles and constriction of efferent arterioles resulting in an 
increased RBF(Because the dilatory effect of ANP on afferent arterioles is more than the 
constrictor effect on efferent arterioles, there is an overall decrease in renal vascular resistance 
and resulting increase in RBF) and increased GFR.
questions.chapter_heading: Acid-Base Balance  Renal Hormones and Micturiti

questions.question: Question 12: ANP secretion is raised by all except
questions.explanation:
It is  in ECF volume and not hypovolemia that causes increased secretion of ANP. 688 
Sold by @itachibot Stimuli that increase the secretion of ANP • atrial stretch or ventricular stretch • isotonic saline administration • ECF volume Stimuli that decrease ANP secretion • Rising from supine to standing position (as this decreases the central venous pressure).
questions.chapter_heading: Acid-Base Balance  Renal Hormones and Micturiti

questions.question:
Question 13: Several hormones regulate the tubular reabsorption of water and electrolytes at different sites 
in the nephron physiologically in a patient. Which of the following combination is correct?
questions.explanation:
The combination which is correct is Aldosterone in collecting ducts. Aldosterone acts on principal cells and intercalated cells, which are present in collecting ducts. It 
regulates ECF volume and Na+ content. Major stimulus for aldosterone secretion 
is Hyperkalemia. The functions of aldosterone are Na+ and H2O reabsorption, K+ and 
H+excretion. Option A: Angiotensin II acts on efferent arteriole. It causes vasoconstriction increasing BP. It 
causes constriction of efferent arteriole, increases filteration fraction, preserving GFR when 
RBF . Option B: ADH acts on principal cells in collecting ducts. It primarily regulates serum osmolarity. 
Stimulates reabsorption of water in collecting ducts via Aquaporin-2. Option D: ANP is released from atria and BNP is released from ventricles in response to  volume, 
it inhibits RAAS, relaxes mesangial cells and promotes natriuresis.
questions.chapter_heading: Acid-Base Balance  Renal Hormones and Micturiti

questions.question: Question 14: The areas associated with micturition reflex is/are
questions.explanation:
The micturition center is located in the pons. The paracentral lobule is also associated with 
micturition. The micturition reflex is an autonomic spinal cord reflex, but it can be inhibited or facilitated by 
centers in the brain. These centers include- • A strong facilitative and inhibitory centers in the brain stem, located mainly in the pons. • Centers located in the cerebral cortex that are mainly inhibitory but can become excitatory.
questions.chapter_heading: Acid-Base Balance  Renal Hormones and Micturiti

questions.question:
Question 15: Hypoxia-induced factors stimulate  
 cells of the kidney to initiate erythropoiesis.
questions.explanation:
Hypoxia induced factors stimulate interstitial cells to initiate erythropoiesis Erythropoietin is produced by interstitial cells in the peritubular capillary bed of the kidney. 689 
Sold by @itachibot Erythropoietin inturn initiates erythropoiesis
questions.chapter_heading: Acid-Base Balance  Renal Hormones and Micturiti

questions.question: Question 16: Choose the correct option mentioning the correct site of product conversion
questions.explanation:
Angiotensin 1  angiotensin 2 @ lungs Cholecalciferol  25 hydroxy vitamin D3 @ liver 25 hydroxy vitamin D3  1,25 dihydroxy vitamin D3 @ Kidney Angiotensin I is converted to Angiotensin II by Angiotensin Converting Enzyme (ACE) which is 
expressed in the lungs.
questions.chapter_heading: Acid-Base Balance  Renal Hormones and Micturiti

questions.question: Question 17: ADH acts through which aquaporin channel?
questions.explanation:
The antidiuretic hormone acts through aquaporin channel 2. ADH binds to V2 receptors in the late distal tubules, collecting tubules, and collecting ducts, and 
stimulates the movement of an intracellular protein, called aquaporin-2 (AQP-2), to the luminal 
side of the cell membranes.
questions.chapter_heading: Acid-Base Balance  Renal Hormones and Micturiti

questions.question: Question 18: Ureteric peristalsis is mainly due to

options.d: Pacemaker activity of smooth muscles of renal pelvis

questions.explanation:
Urine flowing from the collecting ducts into the renal calyces stretches the calyces and increases 
their inherent pacemaker activity, which in turn initiates peristaltic contractions occurring 1 to 5 
times per minute that spread to the renal pelvis and then downward along the length of the 
ureter, thereby forcing urine from the renal pelvis toward the bladder. 690 
Sold by @itachibot • The walls of the ureters contain smooth muscle and are innervated by both sympathetic and 
parasympathetic nerves, as well as by an intramural plexus of neurons and nerve fibers that 
extends along the entire length of the ureters. • As with other visceral smooth muscle, peristaltic contractions in the ureter are • Enhanced by parasympathetic stimulation • Inhibited by sympathetic stimulation
questions.chapter_heading: Acid-Base Balance  Renal Hormones and Micturiti

questions.question: Question 19: In micturition reflex, the first change to occur is
questions.explanation:
• One of the initial events is the relaxation of the muscles of the pelvic floor, and this may cause a 
sufficient downward tug on the detrusor muscle to initiate its contraction. • Micturition Reflex • Micturition is fundamentally a spinal reflex facilitated and inhibited by higher brain centers and 
is subject to voluntary facilitation and inhibition. • These centers include • strong facilitative and inhibitory centers in the brain stem, located mainly in the pons • several centers located in the cerebral cortex that is mainly inhibitory but can become excitatory. • The micturition reflex is the basic cause of micturition, but the higher centers normally exert 
final control of micturition. • Micturition Reflex is the result of a stretch reflex initiated by sensory stretch receptors in the 
bladder wall, especially by the receptors in the posterior urethra when this area begins to fill with 
urine at the higher bladder pressures. • Sensory signals from the bladder stretch receptors are conducted to the sacral segments of the 
cord through the pelvic nerves and then reflexively back again to the bladder through the 
parasympathetic nerve fibers by way of these same nerves. (refer figure) • As the bladder continues to fill, the micturition reflexes become more frequent and cause greater 
contractions of the detrusor muscle. • Once a micturition reflex begins, it is “self-regenerative.” • It is a single complete cycle of • The progressive and rapid increase of pressure, • A period of sustained pressure, and • Return of the pressure to the basal tone of the bladder. • As the bladder becomes more and more filled, micturition reflexes occur more and more often 
and more and more powerfully. • Once the micturition reflex becomes powerful enough, it causes another reflex, which passes 
through the pudendal nerves to the external sphincter to inhibit it. If this inhibition is more 
potent in the brain than the voluntary constrictor signals to the external sphincter, urination will 
occur. If not, urination will not occur until the bladder fills still further and the micturition reflex 691 
Sold by @itachibot becomes more powerful.
questions.chapter_heading: Acid-Base Balance  Renal Hormones and Micturiti

questions.question: Question 20: How much urine in the bladder will cause the first urge to void in a patient?
questions.explanation:
The first urge to void is felt at a bladder volume of about 150 mL, and a marked sense of fullness 
at about 400 mL. Cystometrogram (refer figure) A plot of intravesical pressure against the volume of fluid in the bladder is called a 
cystometrogram. The curve shows • An initial slight rise in pressure when the first increments in the volume are produced(Ia); • A long, nearly flat segment as further increments are produced(Ib); 692 
Sold by @itachibot • A sudden, sharp rise in pressure as the micturition reflex is triggered(II). • The flatness of segment Ib is a manifestation of the law of Laplace. • This law states that the pressure in a spherical viscus is equal to twice the wall tension divided by 
the radius. • P= 2T/R • In the case of the bladder, the tension increases as the organ fill but so does the radius. 
Therefore, the pressure increase is slight until the organ is relatively full.
questions.chapter_heading: Acid-Base Balance  Renal Hormones and Micturiti

questions.question:
Question 21: In a patient, pO2 is 85mmHg, pCO2 is 50mmHg, pH is 7.2, and HCO3- is 36mmol/L. Identify 
the condition.

options.a: Respiratory acidosis with compensatory metabolic alkalosis
options.c: Respiratory alkalosis with compensatory metabolic acidosis
options.d: Respiratory acidosis with compensatory metabolic acidosis

questions.explanation:
This patient has respiratory acidosis with compensatory metabolic alkalosis. pH is decreased (<7.35) so it is acidosis. The CO2 levels are increased (>45mmHg), which is in line with the change in pH (in 
respiratory acidosis CO2 is expected to raise), thus the primary problem is respiratory. The HCO3- levels are increased (>30mmol/L), which is opposite to change in pH (i.e there is 
acidosis and HCO3- levels are high), thus, there is compensatory metabolic alkalosis. Thus, this is a case of respiratory acidosis with compensatory metabolic alkalosis.
questions.chapter_heading: Acid-Base Balance  Renal Hormones and Micturiti

questions.question:
Question 22: A patient with salicylic acid poisoning has the following arterial blood gas analysis report: pH 
= 7.1, pCO2 =18mmHg, HCO3-=12mmol/L. Identify the acid-base disorder here.

options.b: Respiratory acidosis with compensatory metabolic alkalosis
options.c: Metabolic acidosis with uncompensated respiratory alkalosis

questions.explanation:
The acid-base disorder here is a mixed disorder of metabolic acidosis and respiratory alkalosis. It should not be confused with metabolic acidosis with uncompensated respiratory alkalosis. This 
can be understood by the following calculation: Step 1: The pH in this patient is 7.1 (pH <7.35) which indicates acidosis 693 
Sold by @itachibot Step 2: HCO3- is 12 mmol/L (Normal HCO3- - 22–30 mmol/L). In metabolic acidosis, 
HCO3- levels decrease. Hence, this is a case of metabolic acidosis. Step 3: As per Winter's formula, the expected respiratory compensation in metabolic acidosis can 
be calculated using, pCO2 =( 1.5 x [HCO3-] ) +8 ± 2 In this case, Expected pCO2 = ( 1.5 x [12] ) +8 ± 2 = 26 ± 2 = 24 - 28 mmHg The pCO2 in this patient is 18 mmHg, which implies there is an overcompensation of pCO2. This 
overcompensation can happen only if there is an additional component of respiratory alkalosis 
contributing to reduced pCO2. Hence, this patient has a mixed disorder - metabolic acidosis and respiratory alkalosis.
questions.chapter_heading: Acid-Base Balance  Renal Hormones and Micturiti

questions.question: Question 23: Which of the following patients will have metabolic alkalosis?

options.b: A patient with chronic renal failure who is recommended dialysis
options.c: A patient who was diagnosed with hyperaldosteronism
options.d: A patient who took a whole bottle of aspirin to get rid of the headache

questions.explanation:
Metabolic alkalosis is seen in patients with hyperaldosteronism. In hyperaldosteronism: increased aldosterone levels cause increased H+ secretion by the distal 
tubule and increased reabsorption of HCO3-  Metabolic alkalosis.
questions.chapter_heading: Acid-Base Balance  Renal Hormones and Micturiti

questions.question: Question 24: In a patient with metabolic acidosis, which of the following changes are seen?
questions.explanation:
K+ secretion into the renal tubules is decreased when the H+ secretion is increased (Intracellular 
Buffering of H+). Thus in metabolic acidosis, there is decreased K+ excretion.
questions.chapter_heading: Acid-Base Balance  Renal Hormones and Micturiti

questions.question: Question 25: A normal anion gap metabolic acidosis occurs in patients with
questions.explanation:
Diarrhoea is a cause of normal anion gap metabolic acidosis produced as a result of increased 
HCO3- loss in feces. This is because a decrease in HCO3- is replaced by an increase in the concentration of Cl-. This is 
a measurable anion and hence the anion gap is normal. Extra - edge : Siggard-Anderson curve normogram is used to plot the acid-base composition of the 
blood 694 
Sold by @itachibot Pituitary and Thyroid
questions.chapter_heading: Acid-Base Balance  Renal Hormones and Micturiti
